utterances: He says, hey look, I just shot some game, you want this, or should we eat it for dinner?
So, Darwin looks quickly and he says, ah, let's eat it.
So, the cook cooks it up, and he serves it.
And Darwin's about halfway through his meal.
And they're eating and all of a sudden, Darwin jumps up and yells, wait, stop.
Why?
He realized at that moment, and he says...
What do you mean?
That the bird that they were eating was the one he was seeking?
Exactly.
Oh, no.
And he had seen it.
(unintelligible)
Is it already, like, in the pot and everything?
It's cooked.
Oh, no.
It is cooked and eaten.
So, he went to the kitchen mess and he found, you know, the neck bones, the head, the feet, any pluckings of the feathers.
And he took all of these, you know, bits and pieces of the poor Rhea, and he packaged them up, and he sent them to London.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
So, you know, he fished out - did he take stuff off people's plates?
I guess he must have, if they had both.
He took- if there were bones, he took them.
He took every little bit that he could find.
And he mailed it all to a friend, a taxidermist in London by the name of John Gould.
Gould knew exactly what to do about this.
He constructed a bird out of wire and wet skin that he had.
And then he pasted on any feathers that Darwin had provided of this bird.
And then he stole matching feathers from other birds and the much more common Greater Rhea, of which there were several specimens, so...
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

Having, in effect, reconstructed the bird from stew, when Darwin came back from his trip, Gould formerly presented the bird at a special ceremony of the Zoological Society in London and announced that since Darwin had caught the bird, it should be named in his honor, Rhea darwinii.
And Darwin, you know - no, no, it's too much.
But, of course, he was thrilled with it.
Wait, wait, wait, wait a second.
What about the French guy who had already at least described...
Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Back in France - the French version of the London Zoological Society published in their magazine that Alcid D'Orbigny had described the bird, and D'Orbigny himself named it Rhea pennata, pennata meaning feathers.
So, the people...
Okay.
So, now we have a contest, don't we?
Now we have - yeah, now we have a little...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Well, they were battling for ostrich supremacy.
It is England versus France.
It's Darwin versus D'Orbigny.
It's, I've got the specimen and you don't.
Although don't you think that if the specimen that Darwin got was taken out of some stew...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
And was wearing some other feathers from some other bird, that maybe he didn't - really shouldn't win, you know?
Yeah, you know...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Because the French do stick with pennata, the British stick with darwinii, but then time passes - is that we say in the story?
Yeah, time passes.
And when scientists later weighed Darwin's claims against D'Orbigny's, you know what?
The bird today is not officially called darwinii.
Its scientific name is pennata.
So the French - the French won.
And Darwin, well, did he get his name on any bird?
Is there any animal...
Yeah.
There's a little...
Oh.
So, let's hear the consolation prize.
What does he have a name for?
Oh, dear.
He's got a little, partridge-like bird.
Is it the Lesser Tinamou?
Well, actually, it's a little less than the Lesser Tinamou.
Darwin's name is now on a very teeny bird called the Least Tinamou.
It's not what he hoped for.
But you can't have everything.
Robert Krulwich, NPR News, New York.
